2.   You say that gurus are unnecessary, but how can I find truth without the wise help and guidance which only a guru can give?

3.   In order to have peace of mind, must I not learn to control my thoughts?

4.   Why don’t you feed the poor instead of talking?

5.   In your talks in 1944, the following question was put to you: “You are in a happy position. All your needs are met. We have to earn money for ourselves, our wives and families. We have to attend to the world. How can you understand us and help us?” That is the question.

6.   What is the purpose of prayer?

7.   What is right education? As teachers and as parents, we are confused.

8.   What do you mean by living from moment to moment?

9.   The more I listen to you, the more I feel the truth of the ancient teachings of Christ, Shankara, the Bhagavad-Gita, and Theosophy. Have you really not read any of them?

10. What exactly do you mean by meditation? Is it a process or a state?

Madras, 1949-50

1.   We see inequality among men, and some are far above the rest of mankind. Surely, then, there must be higher types of beings like Masters and devas who may be deeply interested in cooperating with mankind. Have you contacted any of them? If so, can you tell us how we can contact them?

2.   In one of your talks you have stated that if a person prays, he receives, but he will pay for it in the end. What do you mean by this?

3.   There is widespread misery in the world, and all religions have failed, yet you seem to be talking religion more and more. Will any religion help us to be free from misery?

4.   It has been said that the acquirement of wisdom is the ultimate goal of life, and that wisdom has to be sought little by little through a life of purification and dedication, with the mind and the emotions directed to high ideals through prayer and meditation. Do you agree?

5.   We all experience loneliness; we know its sorrow and see its causes, its roots. But what is aloneness? Is it different from loneliness?

6.   You have been talking for a number of years about transformation. Do you know of anyone who has been transformed in your sense of the word?

7.   You have never talked about the future. Why? Are you afraid of it?

8.   What should be the relationship, according to you, between the individual and the state?

9.   You have talked about relationship based on usage of another for one’s own gratification, and you have often hinted at a state called love. What do you mean by love?

Colombo, 1949-50

1.   You say that you are not going to act as a guru to anyone. Cannot one who has understood the truth convey his understanding to another to help him also to understand?

2.   You are reported as having said that ideas are not going to bring people together. Please explain how, according to you, people can be brought together to create a better world.

3.   I feel uncertain about everything and consequently find it difficult to act well, as I fear that my action will only lead to further confusion. Is there a way I can act to avoid confusion?

4.   You are reported as having said that religion cannot provide a solution to the problems of humanity. Is that correct?

5.   Why do you waste your time preaching instead of helping the world in a practical way?

6.   I am a teacher, and after studying what you say, I see that most of the present education is harmful or futile. What can I do about it?

7.   I am a smoker, and I am trying to break myself of the habit of smoking. Can you help me?

8.   Is continence or chastity necessary for the attainment of liberation?

9.   The idea of death terrifies me. Can you help me to overcome the dread of my own death and that of my loved ones?

10. Do you advocate vegetarianism? Would you object to the inclusion of an egg in your diet?

11. You say that reality or understanding exists in the interval between two thoughts. Will you please explain.

12. What happens to an individual at death? Does he continue, or does he go to annihilation?

13. I pray to God, and my prayers are answered. Is this not proof of the existence of God?

14. Why don’t you participate in politics or in social reform?

15. Do you believe in reincarnation and karma?

16. Why are you against nationalism?

17. What do you mean when you say that the thinker and the thought are one?

18. Is belief in God necessary or helpful?

19. What is the simple life, and how can I live a simple life in the modern world?

20. I find that loneliness is the underlying cause of many of my problems. How can I deal with it?

21. You lay great emphasis on being aware of our conditioning. How can I understand my mind?

22. What is right meditation?

Bombay, 1950

1.   Our lives are empty of any real impulse of kindness, and we seek to fill this void with organized charity and compulsive justice. Sex is our life. Can you throw any light on this weary subject?

2.   India has an ancient tradition of simple living and few wants. At present, however, millions are held in the grip of involuntary poverty and privation, while at the other end of the scale this land is dominated by the rich upper classes who are already living a European mode of life. How can one discover the right relationship to possessions and comforts?

3.   What is self-knowledge? The traditional approach to self-knowledge is the knowledge of atma as distinct from the ego. Is that what you mean by self-knowledge?

4.   You assert that you have not read a single book, but do you really mean it? Don’t you know that such loose statements cause resentment? You appear to know the latest jargon of politics, economics, psychology, and the sciences; and are you trying to suggest that you get all this information by some superhuman powers?

5.   Is beauty to be cultivated or acquired? What does beauty mean to you?

6.   Through such movements as the United Nations Organization and the World Pacifist Conferences recently held in India, men all over the world are making an individual and collective effort to prevent the third world war. How does your attempt differ from theirs, and do you hope to have any appreciable results?

7.   You repeat again and again that the mind must cease for reality to come into existence. Why then do you attack prayer, worship, and ceremonials, which are really meant to still the mind?

8.   One watches the people near you for any visible sign of transformation. How do you explain that, while you walk in light, your nearest followers remain dull and ugly in their life and their behavior?

9.   The more one listens to you, the more one feels that you are preaching withdrawal from life. I am a clerk in the Secretariat; I have four children, and I get only Rs. 125 a month. Will you please explain how I can fight the gloomy struggle for existence in the new way you are proposing? Do you really think that your message can mean anything significant to the starving and to the stunted wage earner? Have you lived among such people?

10. The conscious mind is ignorant and afraid of the unconscious mind. You are addressing mainly the conscious mind, and is that enough? Will your method bring about release of the unconscious?

11. Why does the human mind cling so persistently to the idea of God in many different ways? Can you deny that belief in God has brought consolation and meaning to lonely and desolate people all over the world?

12. You seem to be preaching something very akin to the teachings of the Upanishads; why then are you upset if someone quotes from sacred books? Do you mean to suggest that you are expounding something no one has ever said before?

13. You are preaching a kind of philosophical anarchism, which is the favorite escape of the highbrow intellectuals. Will not a community always need some form of regulation and authority? What social order could express the values you are upholding?

14. Prayer is the only expression of every human heart; it is the cry of the heart for unity. All schools of Bhaktimarga are based on the instinctive bent for devotion. Why do you brush it aside as a thing of the mind?

15. Do you accept the law of reincarnation and karma as valid, or do you envisage a state of complete annihilation?

16. Will you please explain the process of your mind when you are actually speaking here. If you have not gathered knowledge, and if you have no store of experience and memory, from where do you get your wisdom?

17. How can I as an individual meet, overcome, and resolve the growing tension and war fever between India and Pakistan? This situation creates a mentality of revenge and mass retaliation. Inaction is a crime. How does one meet a problem like this?

18. We know sex as an inescapable physical and psychological necessity, and it seems to be a root cause of chaos in the personal life of our generation. It is a horror to young women who are victims of man’s lust. Suppression and indulgence are equally ineffective. How can we deal with this problem?

19. When you say love is the only solvent of life’s problems, you are giving a connotation to the word which we have hardly experienced. Can a common man like me ever know love in your sense?

20. The question of what is truth is an ancient one, and no one has answered it finally. You speak of truth, but we do not see your experiments or efforts to achieve it, as we saw in the lives of people like Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. Besant. Your pleasant personality, your disarming smile and soft love, is all that we see. Will you explain why there is such a difference between your life and the lives of other seekers of truth. Are there two truths?

21. Political freedom has not yet brought a new faith and joy. We find everywhere cynicism, communal and linguistic antagonism, and class hatred. What is your diagnosis and remedy for this tragic situation?

22. Can the starving and ignorant people of this land understand your message? How can it have any meaning or significance for them?

23. Are you not against institutional marriage?

24. Why are you trying to shake our belief in God and religion? Is not some faith necessary for spiritual endeavor, both individual and collective?

Paris, 1950

1.   The only weapon you give to the victims of social injustice is self-knowledge. This, to me, is derision. History teaches us that people have never freed themselves except through violence. The state of society conditions me; therefore, I have to smash it.

2.   My husband was killed during one war, my children died during another, and my house has been destroyed. You say that life is an eternal state of creation, but every spring is broken in me, and I do not find it possible to partake of that renewal.

3.   What is thought? From whence does it come? And what is the relation of the thinker to thought?

4.   Considering the world’s present condition, there must be immediate action on the part of some who are not caught in any system either of the left or of the right. How is this group to be created, and how will it act with regard to the present crisis?

5.   What is the relationship of the individual to society? Has he any responsibility towards it?

6.   What relation has death to life?

7.   As creative individuals may disrupt society according to their own particular idiosyncrasies and capacities, should not creativeness be at the command of society?

8.   I have prayed for my friend’s health, and it has produced certain results. If I now pray to have peace in my heart, can I come in direct contact with God?

9.   Is the individual the result of society or the instrument of society?

10. Why do you speak of the stillness of the mind, and what is this stillness?

11. Why are we afraid of death? And how are we to overcome this fear?

12. What is the process of experience? Is it different from self-consciousness?

13. I cannot conceive of a love which is neither felt nor thought of. You are probably using the word love to indicate something else. Is it not so?

14. What is good and what is evil?

15. You say that if I am creative, all the problems will be solved. How am I to change myself so as to be creative?

16. Beyond all superficial fears there is a deep anguish which eludes me. It seems to be the very fear of life - or perhaps of death. Or is it the vast emptiness of life?

17. Is it possible for Westerners to meditate?

18. Is truth absolute?

New York, 1950

1.   What system would assure us of economic security?

2.   What mental attitude would you consider best suited for the achievement of contentment in today’s troubled world, and how would you suggest we attain it?

3.   You say we use physiological needs for our psychological expansion and security. You further show us that security is nonexistent. This gives us a feeling of complete hopelessness and fear. Is this all?

4.   How can I experience God in myself?

5.   How am I to get rid of fear, which influences all my activities?

6.   How can I permanently get rid of sexual desire?

7.   Should I be a pacifist?

8.   I am not loved and I want to be, for without it life has no meaning. How can I fulfill this longing?

9.   I have many friends, but I am in constant fear of being rejected by them. What should I do?

10. What is the place of the individual in society?

11. I love my children, and how am I to educate them to become integrated human beings?

12. Can prayer form the link between life and religion?

13. You have shown me the superficiality and the futility of the life I am leading. I should like to change, but I am trapped by habit and environment. Should I leave everything and everyone and follow you?

14. What is wisdom? Is it dissimilar from knowledge?

15. Though I am young, I am haunted by the fear of death. How am I to overcome this fear?

16. There are several systems of meditation, both Occidental and Oriental. Which do you recommend?

Seattle, 1950

1.   What is my responsibility towards the present world crisis?

2.   Is the individual the instrument of society, or does society exist for the individual?

3.   There are many concepts of God in the world today. What is your thought concerning God?

4.   What system would give man the greatest physical security?

5.   I seek God, truth, understanding. How am I to proceed in finding them?

6.   To me, discipline is necessary to the good life, but you say that discipline is a hindrance to the good life. Please explain.

7.   You have said in one of your talks that the thought process must cease for reality to be. How can we know anything if thought ceases?

8.   How many centuries will it take for the few who understand to bring about a fundamental transformation in the world?

9.   Religions advocate prayer, and for centuries man has found in it his consolation. This concerted effort through the centuries is surely a significant and vital force. Do you deny its importance?

10. At various times in our lives, we have some kind of mystical experience. How do we know that these are not illusions? How can we recognize reality?

11. Will you please explain what you mean by creativeness.

12. Though you tell us it is necessary for the mind to become still if we are to experience reality, yet you do everything in your power to stimulate us to think.

13. I worry a great deal. Can you tell me how I can be free from worry?

14. I love my son. He may be killed in the war. What am I to do?

15. How am I to overcome loneliness?

16. Is there continuity after death?

17. I want to help people. What is the best way?

18. My life seems to be aimless, and as a result my behavior is unintelligent. Should I not have an overall purpose?

19. What objective proof is there of the experiencing of reality? In the search for reality, is not self-confidence necessary?

20. My thoughts wander to such an extent that I find meditation extremely difficult. Is not concentration necessary for meditation?

Madras, 1952

1.   You have been in retreat for the past sixteen months and that, for the first time in your life. May we know if there is any significance in this?

2.   You have condemned discipline as a means of spiritual or other attainment. How can anything be accomplished in life without discipline or at least self-discipline?

3.   We are told that India is rapidly disintegrating. Is this your feeling too?

4.   When the mind ceases to recognize, does it not come to a state of inactivity? What functions then?

5.   If I am myself unable to find truth, how can I prevent my child from being the victim of my conditioning?

6.   What do you feel to be the cause of the great prevalence of mental derangement in the world today? Is it insecurity? If so, what can we do to keep the millions who feel insecure from becoming unbalanced, neurotic, and psychotic?

7.   Is true regeneration of India possible solely through renaissance of arts and the dance?

8.   Have I understood you aright when I say that the solution for all our ills is to put a stop to all recognition and to the vagaries of desire and go beyond it? I have experienced moments of ecstasy, but they drop away soon afterwards, and desires rush in, breaking from the past into the future. Is it possible to annihilate desire once and for all?

9.   What is simplicity? Does it imply seeing very clearly the essentials and discarding everything else?

10. Can I, who am religiously inclined and desirous of acting wholly and integrally, express myself through politics? For, to me, it appears that a radical change is necessary in the political field.

11. Can the root of a problem like greed be completely eradicated by awareness? Are there various levels of awareness?

12. We are all Theosophists interested fundamentally in truth and love, as you are. Could you not have remained in our Society and helped us rather than separate yourself from us and denounce us? What have you achieved by this?

13. I have spent ten of the best years of my life in prison for my political activities which promised great things. Now there is disillusionment, and I feel completely burned out. What am I to do?

14. What is meant by “accepting what is”? How does it differ from resignation?

15. For truth to come, you advocate action without idea. Is it possible to act at all times without idea, that is, without a purpose in view?

16. What makes something I say to another gossip? Is speaking the truth or speaking good or bad about another gossip? Can it be gossip so long as what is said is true?

17. How can individual regeneration alone possibly bring about, in the immediate, the collective well-being of the greatest number, which is the need everywhere?

18. Although you have used the word truth often, I do not recall that you have ever defined it. What do you mean by it?

19. There is an urge in every one of us to see God, reality, truth. Is not the search for beauty the same as the search for reality? Is ugliness evil?

20. You said that it is our idea of fear that stands in the way of facing it. How is one to overcome fear?

21. How can the thinker and the thought be united?

22. How is man to fulfill himself if he has no ideals?

23. You said that truth can come only when one can be alone and can love sorrow. This is not clear. Kindly explain what you mean by being alone and loving sorrow.

24. One starts with good will and the desire to help, but unfortunately, to help constructively, one joins various organizations, political or religio-sociological. Presently, one finds oneself cut off from all goodness and charity. How does this happen?

25. Why do you say that knowledge and belief must be suppressed for truth to be?

26. What is the relationship between what the psychologists call intuition and what you call understanding?

27. You say that life, as we live, is negation, and so there cannot be love. Will you please explain.

28. How can one know if one is deceiving oneself?

29. You say that through identification we bring about separation, division. Your way of life appears to some of us to be separative and isolating and to have caused division among those who were formerly together. With what have you identified yourself?

30. You say there can be cooperation only when you and I are as nothing. How can this be true? Is not cooperation positive action whereas being as nothing is almost unconscious negativity? How can two nothingness be related, and what is there for them to cooperate about?

31. What system of meditation should I follow?

London, 1952

1.   I have been to several psychoanalysts to free myself from the fear which dominates me. I have not been able to get rid of it. Would you kindly suggest how I am to set about freeing myself from this constant oppression.

2.   We all recognize that inward peace and tranquillity of the mind are essential. What is the method or the “how” which you suggest?

3.   I have tried out many of the things you have suggested in your various talks, but I don’t seem to get very far. What is wrong with you or with me?

4.   Is it possible for the ordinary individual to lead a spiritual life without having a set of beliefs or taking part in ceremonies and ritual?

5.   I feel that much of my unhappiness is due to my strong urge to help and advise those I love - and even those I do not love. How can I really see this as domination and interference? Or, how can I know if my help is genuine?

6.   How do you “see” a fact without any reaction - without condemnation or justification, without prejudice or the desire for a conclusion, without wanting to do something about it, without the sense of thine and mine?

7.   I have tried writing down my thoughts with a view to bringing thought to an end, as you once suggested. Do you still suggest this? I have not found it very helpful myself, as it seems to become a sort of diary.

8.   My wife and I quarrel. We seem to like each other, but yet this wrangling goes on. We have tried several ways of putting an end to this ugliness, but we seem unable to be psychologically free of each other. What do you suggest?

9.   Does not what you are talking about require time and leisure? - whereas most of us are occupied with earning a livelihood, which takes most of our time. Are you speaking for those who are old and retired, or for the ordinary man who has to work?

10. I have listened to you now for several years, but what eludes me is this thing which you call the creative being or state. Could you go a little further into the matter.

11. I have lived through two catastrophic world wars. I fought in one and became a displaced person in the other. I realize that the individual who has no control over these events has very little purpose in life. What is the point of this existence?

12. When trying to empty the mind in order to still it, I obtain a kind of blank mind. How do I know that this state is not simply dozing?

13. Unless the mind is occupied, it soon goes to sleep or deteriorates. Should it not be occupied with the more serious things of life?

14. I find a regular group that meets to discuss your teachings tends to become confusing and boring. Is it better to think over these things alone, or with others?

15. What would you say is the most creative way of meeting great grief and loss?

16. For one who is caught in habit, it seems impossible to see the truth of a thing instantaneously. Surely time is needed - time to break away from one’s immediate activity and really seek to go into what has been happening.

17. You have said that neither meditation nor discipline will create a still mind, but only the annihilation of the ‘I’ consciousness. How can the ‘I’ annihilate the ‘I’?

18. I feel deeply moved when you talk. Is this just sentimentality?

19. What is the function of the mind if thought is to come to an end?

20. The memory of an incident recurs over and over again. How is one to be free from the memory of that incident and from the incident itself?

21. How is one to expose the hidden depths of the unconscious?

22. I have done a great many spiritual exercises to control the mind, and the image-creating process has become less powerful. But still I have not experienced the deeper implications of meditation. Would you please go into this.

23. Most earnestly I ask you, what can be the purpose of my life if, as you say, all thought has to cease, all knowledge be suppressed, all memory lost? How do you relate that state of being, whatever it may be according to you, to the world in which we live? What relation has such a being to our sad and painful existence?
